0.title: Supplemental Videos – Deep Learning
0.content: This page collects introductory materials and video tutorials on deep learning fundamentals and neural networks.

2.title: Videos
2.content: But what is a neural network? | Deep learning chapter 1 . Gradient descent, how neural networks learn | DL2 . Backpropagation, intuitively | DL3 .

3.title: Articles & Papers
3.content: FPGA vs. GPU for Deep Learning . Artificial intelligence (AI) is evolving rapidly, with new neural network models, techniques, and use cases emerging regularly. While there is no single architecture that works best for all machine and deep learning applications, FPGAs can offer distinct advantages over GPUs and other types of hardware in certain use cases. Read full article here.

5.title: CS580: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
5.content: Welcome to CS580! Below you’ll find the course syllabus including policies, schedule, and expectations.

6.title: Course Description
6.content: This course introduces core concepts in Artificial Intelligence, including search, knowledge representation, reasoning, machine learning, and ethics in AI.

8.title: Lectures
8.content: This page will contain slides, notes, and related resources for each lecture. Files will be posted as they become available.

9.title: Supplemental Videos – Markov Chains
9.content: This page contains videos and resources to help you understand Markov chains and their applications in AI.

10.title: Videos
10.content: Intro to Markov Chains & Transition Diagrams . Markov Chains & Transition Matrices .

12.title: Mathematical Foundations
12.content: This section provides supplemental resources on mathematical concepts useful for understanding topics in artificial intelligence and computer science. Materials here are especially helpful for review or background support.

13.title: Topics
13.content: Combinations and Permutations . Learn the difference between combinations and permutations, how to compute them, and where they are applied in AI problems involving search, probability, and planning. Learn more details here: Combinations and Permutations .

14.title: Perspectives & Trends
14.content: A collection of selected articles, media features, and expert opinions offering insight into the societal impact, future directions, and ethical considerations surrounding AI.

15.title: AI Governance
15.content: CLOUD SECURITY ALLIANCE PUBLICATIONS ON AI/ML . Download AI Governance white papers on AI Trustability, Explainability, SaaS, ChatGPT Security, LLMs, Offensive Security, Risk Management Framework, Zero Trust, Benchmarking, Healthcare here .

16.title: In the Media
16.content: Inside Elon Musk’s Colossus Supercomputer! . A behind-the-scenes look at xAI’s ambitious infrastructure project. Dr. Neil Degrasse Tyson on “Is Learning Pointless” . A public-facing conversation on education and AI’s role in shaping how we think about learning. The Next Big Thing After Chat-GPT . Reflections and predictions on the post-generative-AI landscape. These resources are not technical but are intended to help you think critically about the broader implications of AI.

24.content: Students must activate their Mason email accounts to receive important University information, including messages related to this class. For help with setup, access options, and troubleshooting, visit Mason Email – Office 365 Support.

25.title: Honor Code Policy
25.content: Mason is an Honor Code university. You are expected to abide by the University’s honor code, as well as the CS department Honor Code.

26.title: Office of Disability Services
26.content: If you are a student with a disability and you need academic accommodation, please see Dr. Tecuci and contact the Office of Disability Services (ODS) at (703) 993-2474. All academic accommodations must be arranged through the ODS: http://ds.gmu.edu/ .

40.title: Course Materials
40.content: All materials can be accessed on Canvas.

42.title: Grading Breakdown
42.content: . | Homework: 30% | Projects: 25% | Quizzes: 5% | Midterm Exam: 20% | Final Exam: 20% | . Unless expressly indicated, all homework must be completed with a text editor (Word, PowerPoint, LaTeX, etc.) and delivered in pdf format. Please note that scanned Apple Pencil (or similar) notes are considered handwritten; Work performed in this manner will be penalized as specified in the task description/rubric.

43.title: Course Policies
43.content: Submission . All homework and projects must be submitted via Gradescope only. This is required for academic integrity and proper grading. A late or missed assignment or quiz is simply missed, unless you have a doctor-certified illness on the day of the deadline that prevents you from submitting. In this scenario, contact the professor no later than 48 hours after the due date and attach the supporting documentation described; otherwise, your case will be dismissed. A submission is considered on time if it is submitted electronically on Gradescope on or before the required submission date/time. Once the submission link is closed, it will not be reopened, and email submissions are not accepted. Each assignment has a specific link for submission, so you must ensure that the correct files are submitted to the corresponding link. For example, if Homework 1 is submitted via the Homework 2 link, it will be marked as an “incorrect submission”, and a grade of 0 will be assigned. You can avoid this by taking a few extra minutes to review your submission after uploading it. It is the responsibility of the student to verify that the files are correct. Please note that resubmissions are not accepted due to wrong file submissions or files that can’t be open. Waiting until the last minute may result in submission errors or failure to submit altogether. Please note that network connection failures or instability will not be accepted as an excuse for late or missed submissions, as there is ample time provided for submission. Submissions via unofficial channels—such as email, chat, or Canvas—will not be accepted or graded. Late Policy . Late submissions will incur a 10% deduction per day unless otherwise noted. Each homework and project allows up to 2 late days maximum. After that, the Gradescope link will be closed, and no further submission will be accepted. Academic Integrity . While conceptual collaboration is encouraged, all submitted homework must be your own. For programming projects, groups of up to 4 students are permitted. Ensure all contributions are clearly documented.

44.title: Tools and Platforms
44.content: . | Canvas: All announcements and quizzes | Gradescope: Homework and project submission | .

45.title: Accessibility and Accommodations
45.content: Students with disabilities are encouraged to contact the Office of Disability Services and notify the instructor at the start of the semester.

46.title: Contact and Communication
46.content: Please allow 24–48 hours for email replies. Use your GMU email and include “CS580” in the subject line to help with filtering and prioritization. Emails that do not follow this guideline may be delayed or missed entirely due to high volume and spam filtering.
